text: hi everyone anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
dmx album
exodus the original rough rider this is
a posthumous record from legendary
rapper dmx who tragically passed away in
april and less than a few months later
we have an entire full-length lp
which is surprising but also in some
ways not dmx
has been an active recording artist for
years he most likely has tons of stuff
in the vault but most importantly he was
a legend in his time
sure while his shine and his life may
have been dampened by his vices
records like it's dark and hell is hot
are still game-changing classics no one
around that time had that bark
in that bite while also showing so much
introspection
darkness and lyrical focus in their
music too i
point all this out to say x had immense
respect from his peers
fellow artists who made sure this
project came together quickly
swizz beatz arab music nas lil wayne
jay-z kanye west are just a handful of
the big names affiliated with this
project
many of whom came through with clutch
beats and features but as happy as i am
to see this record drop while people are
still celebrating x's memory
in pockets it does feel kind of rushed
but exodus can bring it where it counts
friends till the end the lox and x are
back together on the opening track which
just
sounds like hip hop history personified
especially on a spacey hard-hitting
modern era swizby
whole thing feels like a dramatic new
take on an old grimy classic there
is then more swiss sanity from the
pumping beets and siren hits
on bath salts jay-z and nas don't really
let up on their features from this track
either
then x comes through sounding absolutely
manic on the back end
bars about popping people like pimples
the more he raps the more he embraces
this out of control energy that affects
his flow kind of changing it into a rant
then lil wayne is kind of the perfect
pick for the club friendly track dogs
out
there's a beat to it but it's also eerie
enough to be a good foundation
for x's uncompromising grit though i
will say the swizz hook on this track is
a tad bit awkward and after x's verse
the song sort of drags on instrumentally
almost like swizz and arab didn't really
know how to end it
so we're a few tracks in and while up to
now exodus isn't a perfect record
it's about as good as you could hope for
from a posthumous album that came
together so quickly
but after this point all bets are kind
of off
we get a slightly unenthusiastic and
sloppy feature from moneybag yo
on money money money and coming together
with a project like this i get the
temptation to create some sort of bridge
between the old school and the new
school but
he could not sound more out of place on
this project i couldn't think of anyone
whose energy level is so completely
different from x's
especially on the hook as x is just
seething through
money money money
simple
brutal it's classic x then the track
hold me down featuring alicia keys
is an attempt at a spacey anthemic
number but
unfortunately the mix on this one is
totally whacked between
all of the encompassing reverb piano and
bright synthesizers
again unfortunate especially considering
that x is dropping some really personal
and introspective lyrical content here
the following track features a crossover
between dmx
and u2's bono which i suppose
isn't too out there to see the potential
in i mean dmx is a man who
in his heyday collaborated with marilyn
manson
but the clubby beat and plucky lead
melodies on this track
don't quite work with the acoustic
guitars and bono's soaring lead vocals
it feels less like a cohesive singular
song and more like i'm hearing a mashup
of two unfinished tracks
once again i left this track feeling
intrigued by x on the lyrical front but
everything else surrounding that didn't
quite work
following this we have hood blues with
the griselda boys which is
honestly a marriage that makes way more
sense really a match
made in heaven if you were going to pick
anyone from the new school to be
involved in this lp
conway west side and benny do not
disappoint either
especially with standouts like you throw
in shots you better be precise if i
squeeze it twice that's me being polite
and once again
on this track x sounds absolutely
menacing on the back end
we then get take control with snoop dogg
who i am happy to see
on this lp especially considering x's
versus battle with snoop
was one of his last big moments in the
spotlight but yeah this track overall is
an attempt at
a kind of a sexy number but it has
little to no finesse and it's somewhat
of an awkward listen for it i know in
his time x was a versatile artist and
maybe on a project like this you want to
show a little bit of everything but
for me a song like walking in the rain
is so much more appropriate for a record
that's effectively a send-off
as this is easily one of the most moving
moments on the lp lyrically and
certainly
serves as a reminder of how insightful
x's hardships had made him over the
years
then the following letter to my son is
uh the absolutely devastating moment
that i anticipated it would be
toward the very end of this record
hearing x rap in the way that he does
even if it is for a short time
uh you know to his son and kind of
dealing with his vices his demons
and uh the hardships he had gone through
as a result of those and
obviously people related to him as a
result of that is an immense moment as
are the more personal and prayer centric
clips of audio on the back end of the
project too
but with all that being said though i
have to say this project
unfortunately is not anywhere near being
one of x's best
and you know what that really has so
little to do with his talents his
abilities how unique he was as an artist
and more to do again with just this
thing feeling
kind of rushed out a bit honestly i
think with more careful crafting
of the beats and the feature list as
well as curation from whatever
we had left over of x's versus we could
have gotten a project that would have
been spinnable for years to come but
instead we got something so much more
lopsided instead
feeling a strong five to a light six on
this one
tran position have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
let me know in the comments make sure to
subscribe hit the bell
over here next to my head is another
video that you can check out hit that up
or the link to subscribe to the channel
anthonyfantano dmx forever
